G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over the parties and the subject matter of this action pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19, as the amount in controversy is within the jurisdictional limit of the Worcester District Court.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, § 1, as the property that is the subject of this action is located in Worcester, Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 186, § 14, every tenancy in Massachusetts carries with it an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment, which prevents a landlord from directly or indirectly interfering with the tenant’s use and enjoyment of the rental property.

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 285 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.proposition: A landlord’s failure to repair conditions that constitute the "serious interference" with a tenant’s tenancy may constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The court expressly holds that a landlord’s omission—its failure to take measures to remove unlawful actors from common areas under its control—can amount to a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment where that omission causes a serious interference with the tenancy. The opinion states that if the landlord “failed to take any action” to remove such persons and their presence “seriously interferes with the tenancy,” it “may be liable for a breach of the covenant,” directly tying failure to remedy conditions causing serious interference to a quiet enjoyment breach.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy — acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the leasehold. … We do believe, however, that if the defendant has failed to take any measures, especially those measures which can be undertaken relatively easily, to remove unwelcome persons from the property that it owns and controls, and the presence of those persons seriously interferes with the tenancy, then the defendant may be liable for a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850 (.proposition: A landlord’s failure to repair conditions that constitute the "serious interference" with a tenant’s tenancy may constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850 (.support_reasoning: The court reaffirms that negligent failure to repair known defects can violate G.L. c. 186, § 14, and expressly cites prior cases where a landlord’s failure to repair conditions interfering with habitability constituted a breach of quiet enjoyment. While this opinion’s main holding is that a bare statutory lead paint violation is not automatically a § 14 violation, its reasoning makes clear that a landlord’s failure to repair serious conditions, after notice, may amount to a breach of the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850 (.relevant_excerpt: We noted that a landlord’s failure “to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14.” See Cruz, supra at 789, citing Simon v. Solomon, supra at 103 (failure to control floods in tenant’s apartment); Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 761 (1979) (failure to repair leaky roof); Dorgan v. Loukas, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 959, 960 (1985) (failure to bring apartment into habitable condition and keep it so). Today we make clear what was implicit in those rulings: to support the imposition of liability under the quiet enjoyment statute, there must be a showing of at least negligent conduct by a landlord…

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102 (198.proposition: A landlord’s failure to repair conditions that constitute the "serious interference" with a tenant’s tenancy may constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102 (198.support_reasoning: The court explicitly explains the meaning of the covenant of quiet enjoyment and ties it to landlord acts or omissions that seriously interfere with the tenancy, citing common-law quiet enjoyment doctrine. It then applies that concept to the landlord’s failure to prevent repeated flooding, holding that such preventable unsanitary conditions that interfere with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment give rise to liability under the quiet enjoyment statute. This directly supports the idea that failure to repair serious interfering conditions can constitute breach of quiet enjoyment.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102 (198.relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ … Every tenancy is deemed to entail an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb this right during the tenancy…. When the Legislature chose the words ‘quiet enjoyment’ … it must have intended to incorporate these cases into the statute.”
